transcription.text:
70mm cement splicer
 Richard Brown donation
Made from cast iron and the paint is noticeably flaking off. There is still film in the splicer. There is still a piece of blank film inside it.

The title 6.00 PM implies that the pattern at the centre of the carpet depicts the play of light and shadow cast through a window at six o’clock in the evening. But the carpet is always displayed in a windowless gallery and the image itself never changes. We can walk across and leave marks on the carpet, meaning we are unlikely to be tricked by the illusion. By fixing a particular moment of light, the work draws attention to connections between light and our perception of time.

Carbon arc projectors use the first electric light ever invented. Arc lamps were commonly found in streetlamps during the 1870s, gradually replaced by incandescent light in the early 20th century. But in situations that called for a high-intensity light, like movie projectors, arc lamps still had a role.

Carbon arc projectors were common until WWII, and it’s rare to see one as late as the 1950s. Because of the intensity of the light in these projectors, they were mostly used in large auditoriums, despite being designed as a lightweight travelling projector. They were marketed as the best bet for screening 16mm film in tents, at road shows, at fairs in rural areas and outdoors – as long as there was a power source!
(ikrissy210) 35mm movie trailers (Madagascar, Bourne Supremacy, Marie Antonitte, The Other Bolyn Girl, Happy Feet, Kung Fu Panda)

work.title: 35mm film, movie trailers: Madagascar (2005), colour; Marie Antoinette (2006), colour

transcription.text: Bakelite plastic Tru-Vue 3-D viewer & nine copies of Tru Vue film cards.

It's noice, it's different, it's unusual. Gina Riley and Jane Turner's hugely popular Kath & Kim hit screens in 2002, poking fun at Aussie suburbia and spawning a trend of mockumentary-style sitcoms. Meanwhile another female-driven show The Secret Life Of Us was breaking boundaries on Channel 10: Deborah Mailman's casting was a landmark moment for representation of Indigenous Australians in mainstream media. The hit series also acted as a training ground for a whole wave of prominent female filmmakers like Cate Shortland, Ana Kokkinos and Emma Freeman. Public broadcasters SBS and ABC had very different successes with East West 101 for the former – a multicultural police procedural – and animated series Bluey becoming a global phenomenon for the latter.

Skippy had stiff competition for the title of Australia's most beloved (and fictional) marsupial when Blinky Bill debuted in 1993. Based on Dorothy Wall's books, the animated series incorporated environmental messages into its storylines and saw film and video game spin-offs. The analysis of Australian politics got satirical with Frontline, as local TV began to stretch the possibilities of what it could do creatively. While Home & Away was finding mainstream success, teenage soap Heartbreak High premiered in 1994 and tackled heady subjects for the time including racism, homelessness, drug addiction and sexuality. Crucially, it also introduced the phrase "rack off" into the pop-cultural lexicon.

Neighbours, everybody needs good neighbours. But it didn't start out that way, with the now iconic Australian soap first debuting to low ratings on Channel 7 in 1985. Following its cancellation, Channel 10 snapped up the rights and took a more a youthful approach with new cast members Jason Donovan, Guy Pearce and Kylie Minogue. Neighbours creator Reg Watson had another hit with Sons and Daughters, which was modelled off prime-time soaps in the US. One of Australia's first reality programs, Perfect Match, also debuted in 1984, featuring dating-show robot Dexter who mathematically matched contestants with a compatibility score.

David Bowie. Madonna. ABBA. Kylie Minogue. If you were a music act in the 1970s, there was one show you had to be on to solidify your status and that was Countdown. Hosted by Ian 'Molly' Meldrum, the ABC program became an institution during its 13-year run. It was the shining jewel in the crown of Australian TV, which moved to exciting new places in the 70s with the arrival of colour. Channel 10 had the saucy Number 96, comedy found new footing with The Aunty Jack Show and the Special Broadcast Service (SBS) was officially launched in 1979 with the aim of telling multicultural Australian stories.

The 60s might have been the first full decade of Australian television, but there was a surprising lack of it on the small screen as the local industry began to establish itself. In lieu of the necessary infrastructure, shows from the US dominated due to the low-cost of syndication. This all changed with requirements that commercial TV stations begin broadcasting forty per cent Australian content, which led to the first homegrown drama Consider Your Verdict in 1961. The one-hour program ran for 160 episodes on Channel 7 and ushered in a wave of other seminal Aussie shows like Four Corners and Skippy The Bush Kangaroo.
